section.hand:
To my L. Treasuro
r
Au
g
2. 89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 2 August To my L. Treasurer
It may please yo
r
L although I do not omyt to adv
r
tyse
M
r
Secretary
of whatsoever passeth yn this place of any moment
w
ch
I
swade my self alwaies ys im
ted w
th
yo
r
L. yet in
regard of advancing her
Ma
ties
s
vice I cannot otherwyse chuse
but when occasyons ar p
r
s ented interrupt yo
r
most weyghty affaires
w
th
my troublesome letters. In w
ch
respect I do not think
t
I
have had hereto for a more importunate occasyon, then ys offred at
is p
nt
, for yt is certefyed hether
t
e Ennemy hath Rxd
a full paie of all his Arrerages &
t
he hath sent from
Antwerp
toward
Bolduck
32 peeces, of great artellerye
& maketh great
vision of flat bottomed boates, wagons &
bredges & oth
r
necessaryes for a siege & passage of rivers
w
ch
ys generally thought to be for
Hoesden
&
Bommels wieert
albeyt we have advertisement
t
he likewise intendeth a surprise
of
e Iles of
Tertolen
&
Tergoes
where yt ys sayd
t
he hath
sent of late very secretly to sound
e depth of the waters
whatsoever ys purposed, I do fynd
t
these men heer ar gretly
plexed for want of men & meanes & though heertofor
e
p
r
sumptious conceat
of some of
e principal among them
hath caryed away
e rest to take undutifull
conceates
courses
against
hir Ma
ty
yet yf
e Ennemy should p
r
vayle in any of
e
foresayd exploit
, yt may be judged by some tokens of humblenes
w
ch
they shew at this p
nt
,
t
they will flye to hir Ma
tie
for
succour, & omyt no [submission] to be farther assisted, wh
r
uppon
e opportunity
s
ving I thought to take occasyon to declare my opinion
to yo
r
L. conc
r
ning theyr proceeding in those articles w
ch
were sent me
lately from my
LL.
Yt ys now a moneth since
t
they were
deliv
r
ed to
e
generall States
& I have moved
em often to
make an answer to hir Ma
tye
, but they do alwaies alleadge
t
they have had no aunswer from theyr principals, w
ch
yf they
listed & wer a matter to theyr liking they could easely
cure &
in lesse
en half
e tyme. I do very much doubt heeruppon
t
either they have not, as they promised sent
e articles to theyr principles or els they purposely delay to call uppon
them for an answer. For by all
t
I can conjecture, these
that ar
e cheefest leaders among them ar utterly unwilling
to admyt any new resolutions or constytutions in
e Treaty,
misdoubting
t
w
ch
must ensew of necessity, that they will be
derogatory to
e autority w
ch
they usurp upon
e Counsell.
To give yo
r
L. to und
r
stand what I do fynde by some conference
w
ch
I have had of these matters, ther ar divers in
is place of
good discretion & calling, who think yt altogeth
r
needles for her
Ma
ty
to enter into consulta
o
n w
th
any deputies from hens.
fol.61v
about
e adresse of
e Treaty or such oth
r
demand
as
e
articles impart, But consydering to what extremity these
countreyes ar like to be reduced & in what devotion
e
gen
r
ality doth continew to hir Ma
ty
yf yt might please hir
to set downe
emptorily, w
th
out using theyr advise, & to
declare directly by hir l
re
s to
e generall States & to
e
Counsell of State to
e States of
e
ticular Provinces & to
e
principall Townes, Fyrst in what manner she hath alwayes
und
r
stood
e meanes of
e Treaty & how she doth exspect
t
yt should be ob
s
ved, & secondly what farder matter
she would have
em yeeld unto in respect of theyr owne
security, &
e better government of
e Countrey, & th
r
uppon
will
myse
t
they shalbe
tected w
th
such assistaunce as is
mentioned in
e Treaty, doubtles ys is thought
t
such a
resolute kynde of
ceeding will sooner take [place] [then]
those orderly courses w
ch
hir Ma
ty
doth propose, for yt is
most manifest to ev
r
y man here, that
e farr greatest
te
oute of
e common people onely [be] of
e chiefest
sons in
these countryes do not think
t
theyr pensioners & deputyes
ar so wilfull & so precisely &
versly bent, as to stand
w
th
hir Ma
ty
upon point
of no
greter
prejudice to
e State of these
countreyes & full of hindraunce to
e common resistaunce
w
ch
is made agaynst
e Ennemy. This is th'effect of such
talk as I have had w
th
such as ar heer men of
experience & good understanding. W
th
whose opinions I thought
yt my duty to acquaynt yo
r
L.
& so to leave yt to be
furder consydered, as yo
r
L. wysdome shall fynde yt
expedient wherw
th
I take my humble leave. Haige August
89
